questions.text:
You are attending a delivery. A 1200gm, 27 weeks gestation baby is born limp. After doing the routine steps, the baby is gasping. 
What should be the next step?

Start PPV with 21-30% O2

Umbilical artery catheterize

questions.text:
A full-term infant with an estimated weight of 3 kg is apneic at birth. The infant does not respond to stimulation, and after 30 seconds of effective positive-pressure ventilation, the infant's heart rate is 50 bpm. The neonatology fellow intubates the infant and decides to give a dose of epinephrine via the endotracheal tube.

Which of the following is an appropriate dose of epinephrine for the infant in this vignette?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

3ml epinephrine 1:10,000 dilution

questions.text: What is the drug of choice in managing symptomatic bradycardia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Epinephrine is a potent vasopressor and will also increase heart rate. The dose for bradycardia is 0.01 mg/kg IV or IO.

choices.text: Establish vascular access and administer epinephrine.
Establish vascular access and insert an advanced airway.

Defibrillation for pVT

questions.text: A newborn presents with purulent conjunctivitis and pneumonia. Baby has no fever and has normal activity. On the gram stain of the purulent discharge, there is no organism found.  What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Chlamydia trachomatis

Gonococcal conjunctivitis begins with mild inflammation and a serosanguineous discharge. Within 24 hr, the discharge becomes thick and purulent, and tense edema of the eyelids with marked chemosis occurs. If proper treatment is delayed, the infection may spread to involve the deeper layers of the conjunctivae and the cornea. Complications include corneal ulceration and perforation, iridocyclitis, anterior synechiae, and rarely panophthalmitis.

questions.text: A 5yrs old male child presented to the clinic with h/o of recurrent infections. The child had rashes as shown below. Routine blood investigations revealed the patient had low platelets. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis in the kid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome

choices.text: Give full course of DPT vaccine
Nothing is required to be done

Prophylactic Erythromycin

Asymptomatic Case Contacts of Diphtheria
Closely follow x 7 days

Single im benzathine PenG or Erythromycin x 10 days
Diphtheria toxoid

If not received 4th dose, vaccinate

questions.text: Two girls in the same class one diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12 years old close friend is in fear of contracting disease. What advice should be given to her:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Single dose of vaccine

choices.text: Ceftriaxone and ciprofloxacin are the most effective agents for prophylaxis
Rifampin is also an excellent agent for prophylaxis

Prophylaxis is not routinely recommended for medical personnel except those with exposure to aerosols of respiratory secretions, such as through mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, intubation, or suctioning before or in the 24 hr after antibiotic therapy is initiated in the index case.
Neither penicillin nor ampicillin treatment eradicates nasopharyngeal carriage and should not be routinely used for prophylaxis

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true about post exposure prophylaxis of neisseria meningitidis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rifampin is most widely used but fails to eradicate colonization in 15% of cases

questions.text:
A 14 year old male is on chemotherapy for ALL. He presents with fever, cough and hypoxia. On examination, he is tachypneic with increased work of breathing. Breath sounds are clear on auscultation. He is started on cefepime, but hypoxia worsens needed mechanical ventilation. His X Ray shows bilateral hazy opacities. His BAL silver stain shows pneumocystis. 
What should be the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Initiate trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and prednisolone

TMP-SMX is the drug of choice for P carinii. Prednisolone should also be given in moderate to severe disease in pO2<70mmHg.
Atovaquone (750 mg twice daily with food, for patients >13 yr of age) is an alternative treatment that has been used primarily in adults with mild to moderate disease.
Some studies in adults suggest that administration of corticosteroids as
adjunctive therapy to suppress the inflammatory response increases the chances
for survival in moderate and severe cases of P. jirovecii pneumonia

questions.text:
A 30-week-gestation pregnant woman is seen at the obstetrician’s office for a febrile illness. Her symptoms include headache and joint pain. She has had routine prenatal care and no complications of pregnancy. Physical examination reveals the rash shown in figure.  She asks how this illness may affect her newborn.

Of the following, the MOST accurate response is that a likely sequela is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The most likely sequela for the newborn in the vignette is generalized edema. Maternal infection with parvovirus B19 is suggested by arthralgia and a lacy rash. Maternal infection can lead to fetal hydrops, isolated pleural or pericardial effusions in the fetus, intrauterine growth restriction, anemia, and fetal demise. Pregnant women with acute parvovirus B19 infection should be monitored closely; fetal infection is thought to occur in approximately 30% of cases. Fetal deaths have only been described with maternal infections in the first half of pregnancy; they are estimated to occur in 3% to 11% of maternal infections before 20 weeks’ gestation.

Parvovirus B19 infections are often asymptomatic. Clinical manifestations include erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease), characterized by a facial rash with a “slapped cheek” appearance that is followed by a symmetric, lacy or maculopapular, pruritic exanthem of the trunk and extremities.

questions.text:
An 11-month-old female presents with a 3-day history of increased temperature, irritability, decreased appetite, and malaise. Although she was afebrile on the morning of presentation, her parents are now concerned about a rash that they report has been present for only the last several hours. On physical examination, she is afebrile and appears generally well. A blanching macular and maculopapular rash is present on the upper torso, face, and neck. A smaller number of similar lesions are noted on the upper thighs. Despite her relatively reassuring clinical appearance, a lumbar puncture is performed due to the presence of a bulging anterior fontanelle. The fluid is clear with zero WBCs, and no organisms are seen on Gram stain.

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical signs and symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Human herpesvirus 6
 
The patient has signs and symptoms consistent with roseola infantum, caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6). The disease appears throughout the year with peak prevalence between 7–13 months. A bulging fontanelle may be noted in as many as 25% of all infants and young children with this disorder, prompting additional evaluation for meningitis. Lymphadenopathy, especially in the postauricular and occipital areas and along the cervical chains are almost universal. Other common clinical signs and symptoms of HHV-6 include irritability, anorexia, injection of the tympanic membranes, and Nagayama spots (an exanthema of red papules located on the soft palate). Upper respiratory symptoms are less common.

Febrile seizures occur in up to 4–5% of patients. Rash, characterized by blanching macular or maculopapular lesions beginning on the neck and trunk and then spreading to the extremities, typically appears as the fever abates. Roseola is generally a benign disease that may be diagnosed clinically and treated supportively. However, a lumbar puncture must be performed in those with a bulging fontanelle to rule out more serious disease.

choices.text: Bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis associated with fissured, dry, cracked, and erythematous lips and cervical adenopathy
Multiple, small, maculopapular erythematous lesions involving mainly the hands and feet
A petechial rash on the extremities with prominence over the wrists and ankles and associated with edema of the hands and feet
Multiple, grouped, vesicular lesions (some of which have ulcerated) covering the tongue and buccal mucosa and associated with gingival edema and erythema
A confluent erythematous rash that is most prominent over the trunk and associated with coryza and conjunctivitis

questions.text:
A 16-month-old boy presents with a 48-hour history of subjective fever, cough, decreased activity, and decreased appetite. Findings on physical examination are limited to numerous small, irregular, erythematous spots with a minute, bluish-white center located on the buccal mucosa.
Which of the following clinical findings is most likely to be identified in this patient within the next several days?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

A confluent erythematous rash that is most prominent over the trunk and associated with coryza and conjunctivitis
The patient has clinical findings consistent with Koplik spots, which characteristically precede the exanthem of rubeola (measles virus infection). Because they resolve by the time the rash appears, Koplik spots usually go undetected unless identified during evaluation of a patient with nonspecific symptoms prior to the onset of rash. A prodrome of cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis (the “3 Cs”) characteristically precede the onset of the rash. Measles is a highly contagious Morbillivirus of the Paramyxoviridae family. Patients are contagious from 3–5 days prior to onset of the rash through 4 days following it. The erythematous, blanching, maculopapular rash quickly becomes confluent (morbilliform), spreading cephalocaudally and
centrifugally. The rash lasts from 4–6 days. Measles may be complicated by
bronchopneumonia, otitis media, croup, or acute encephalitis (about 1 in 1000 cases). Death may also occur from respiratory or neurologic compromise in about 1/1000 to 3/1000 cases in the United States. The MMR vaccine is routinely recommended at 12–15 months and 4–6 years of age. However, the 2 dose may be administered as soon as 1 month following the 1 dose. Because Koplik spots are pathognomonic for measles, the remainder of the answers can quickly be ruled out, as they do not describe symptoms consistent with measles infection


The patient has signs and symptoms consistent with roseola infantum, caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6). The disease appears throughout the year with peak prevalence between 7–13 months. A bulging fontanelle may be noted in as many as 25% of all infants and young children with this disorder, prompting additional evaluation for meningitis. Lymphadenopathy, especially in the postauricular and occipital areas and along the cervical chains are almost universal. Other common clinical signs and symptoms of HHV-6 include irritability, anorexia, injection of the tympanic membranes, and Nagayama spots (an exanthema of red papules located on the soft palate). Upper respiratory symptoms are less common.

Febrile seizures occur in up to 4–5% of patients. Rash, characterized by blanching macular or maculopapular lesions beginning on the neck and trunk and then spreading to the extremities, typically appears as the fever abates. Roseola is generally a benign disease that may be diagnosed clinically and treated supportively. However, a lumbar puncture must be performed in those with a bulging fontanelle to rule out more serious disease.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy presents with a 2-day history of rash and subjective fever. He takes no daily medications and has no known drug, food, or environmental allergies. On physical examination, he is afebrile and looks well. Bright red, erythematous, nontender patches are noted over both cheeks, sparing the circumoral area. A macular blanching rash also is noted over the extensor surfaces of the upper extremities. The patient’s mother is currently pregnant and at 11 weeks of gestation.

Which of the following fetal complications is associated with the etiologic agent of this child’s rash?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Nonimmune fetal hydrops

The patient has clinical findings consistent with erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), caused by parvovirus B19. Characterized by an erythematous, patchy exanthem over the cheeks (“slapped cheeks”) and a “lacy-reticular” rash on the upper extremities, affected children are otherwise well or exhibit only mild constitutional symptoms. However, erythema infectiosum is a mildly contagious illness, which, if transmitted to a susceptible pregnant woman, may cause intrauterine growth restriction, isolated pleural and pericardial effusions, nonimmune hydrops fetalis (fetal hydrops), and intrauterine demise.

questions.text: Short cervix is a known risk factor for preterm labor. What cervical length (measured by transvaginal ultrasound) is considered a significant predictor of preterm birth?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Less than 25mm

A cervical length of less than 25 mm, as measured by transvaginal ultrasound during the second trimester (typically between 18–24 weeks), is a well-established and significant predictor of preterm birth. A short cervix indicates a higher risk of premature cervical remodeling and potential dilation, which can lead to preterm labor. This threshold is widely used in both screening and decision-making for interventions such as progesterone supplementation or cerclage in high-risk pregnancies. The <25>

questions.text: Intussusception is complication of …………….vaccine
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rota Virus

questions.text: A neonatologist evaluates a male newborn with dysmorphic facial features. After examining the infant, the neonatologist suspects that the infant has Apert syndrome. Of the following, which is likely to be found in this infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Craniosynostosis

Apert syndrome, also known as acrocephalosyndactyly, is a sporadic disorder with an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. This syndrome is caused by a mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 2 gene. The features of affected neonates include the following: craniosynostosis, hypertelorism, midfacial hypoplasia, and broad distal phalanxes of the thumb and big toe. Patients may also have congenital heart disease, including a ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, and an overriding aorta.
Crouzon syndrome, also known as craniofacial dysotosis, has some similarities with Apert syndrome

questions.text: A 4year old boy is seen for a health supervision visit. He has eczema and has had recurrent ear infections that required the placement of myringotomy tubes. He attends preschool, knows his letters, and can draw a triangle and a square. He is interactive during the physical examination His height is at the 30th percentile, his weight is at the 50th percentile, and his head circumference is at the 70th percentile. He can hop on one foot for 2 seconds and sing his favourite nursery rhyme. His mother reports that his father, paternal uncle, and grandmother have short stature, a large head, small fingers, and shortening of both arms and thighs. His father has been relatively healthy except for obstructive sleep apnea. His grandmother had stenosis of the lumbar spine and hearing loss. His uncle recently had a newborn son with a large head and short limbs who underwent ventriculoperitoneal shunt insertion because of obstructive hydrocephalus Of the following the inheritance pattern of the disorder MOST likely seen in this family is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The disorder seen in the family described in the vignette is achondroplasia. Achondroplasia is characterized by disproportionate short stature with rhizomelic (proximal segment) Shortening and macrocephaly. Facial features include a depressed nasal bridge with retrusion of the mid face and frontal bossing. Achondroplasia is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern with complete penetrance all patients who carry the pathogenic variant will exhibit signs and symptoms of the disorder. The patient in the Vignette is not affected with achondroplasia, because he is of normal height and does not have macrocephaly or rhizomelic shortening. Affected family members include the patient' s father, paternal uncle, uncle's son and paternal grandmother.

Other features seen in achondroplasia include limitation of elbow extension, a trident
configuration of the hands, bowed legs, and exaggerated lumbar lordosis once the child begins to walk Individuals with achondroplasia have normal intelligence and life span Early motor delay is common owing to hypotonia. Complications of the disorder include a nisk of increased intracranial pressure owing to obstructive hydrocephalus, craniocervical junction compression, obstructive sleep apnea, conductive hearing loss, persistent kyphosis, and spinal stenosis (in adults). Owing to risk of these complications, surveillance after diagnosis includes baseline imaging of the craniocervical junction ongoing assessment of hearing, development, an growth and a low threshold for evaluation of spinal stenosis in adults.

questions.text: An infant is being investigated for persistent jaundice and has a systolic murmur consistent with pulmonary valve disease. Ophthalmological assessment reveals an anterior-segment abnormality. What is the most likely skeletal manifestation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Alagille syndrome has all these features.

questions.solution:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy

questions.solution:

XL dominant

questions.text: What is the inheritance of Coffin lowry and Aicardi syndromes?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A neonate is diagnosed with supravalvular subaortic stenosis. Upon examination you note hypoplastic nails, prominent lips, and a stellate iris pattern. Which of the following microdeletions is responsible for this neonate’s likely syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

7q11.23
 
The neonate in the above scenario most likely has Williams syndrome. It is caused by a 7q11.23 deletion of an elastin gene. Approximately 50% to 70% of affected individuals have cardiac manifestations with supravalvular subaortic stenosis being the most common finding. Other findings include the following:
•    Hypoplastic nails
•    Prominent lips
•    Hoarse voice
•    Stellate iris pattern
•    Mental deficiency
•    Renal anomalies
•    Transient hypercalcemia

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is NOT commonly caused by a microdeletion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Holt-Oram syndrome

    Holt-Oram syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder with variable expression. Affected children often presenting with the following:
•    Cardiac defects (atrial septal defect is the most common)
•    Upper limb defects
•    Absent, hypoplastic or abnormally shaped thumbs
•    Narrow shoulders
•    Hypertelorism

questions.text:
A 4 year-old boy  is seen for a health supervision visit He was born at fill item to a 5-year-old mother. The mother reports that at age 30 years she underwent fertility treatments because of premature ovarian failure. The boy has delayed speech and can say only 10 words. He is very active and runs around the room during the entire visit. The mother expresses concern about his behavior, frequent temper tantrums, hand flapping, and biting his 2-year old sister. The family history is significant for bipolar disorder in the maternal grandmother and Parkinson disease in the maternal grandfather The family history on the maternal side is unknown.

  

Of the following, the MOST likely underlying etiology of this boy s clinical disorder is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The condition seen in the family described in the vignette is FMRI-related disorder caused by expansion of CGG repeats in the FMRI gene. The CGG repeats are preset in the promoter region of the FMRI gene located on the X-chromosome. The clinical picture depends on the number of CGG repeats present in the individual. Individuals with a full mutation (200 repeats) exhibit features of fragile X syndrome with developmental delay, behavioural issues such as attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, and autism-spectrum disorder. Physical examination findings include a facial profile with long face, prominent forehead, prominent jaw, and large ears. Macroorchidism can be seen in postpubertal males. Females with full mutation can have a variable presentation according to the degree of tissue-specific X-inactivation of the affected allele.

questions.text: The inheritance of NARP syndrome is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

mitochondrial

questions.text: What is the inheritance in the below shown image?

Genomic imprinting eg Prader willi syndrome

questions.text: What is the inheritance of pseudohypoparathyroidism Ib?

questions.text:
Vijay is a 5-month-old infant who has  been seen repeatedly by his general practitioner because of colic. His mother brings him to the Accident and Emergency department as he is having episodes of suddenly throwing his head and arms forward. These episodes occur in repetitive bursts. His mother thinks they may be something more than just colic, as he is now not smiling or supporting his head as well as  he did previously. He was born at term by normal vaginal delivery and has no other medical problems. His EEG is shown in

 
He has history of acne like lesions on  his face and suspicious lesion in his ventricle. What is the best drug for him?

questions.text:
George, a 2-week-old male  infant, presents to the Emergency Department with vomiting, diarrhoea and poor feeding.

Investigations show:

•    sodium 112 mmol/L (normal range 133– 145 mmol/L)

•    potassium 6.8 mmol/L (normal range 3.5–6.0 mmol/L)

•    urea 7.8 mmol/L (normal range 2.5–8.0 mmol/L)

•    creatinine 30 mmol/L (normal range 20– 65 mmol/L) 

•    blood glucose 1.7 mmol/L (normal range>2.6 mmol/L)

•    infection screen—negative What is the most likely cause? Select one answer only.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CAH

questions.text:
Salman, a 5-year-old boy,  recently had   a birthday party at his local farm. Since then he has had 3 days of diarrhoea. The loose stool had some blood in it. His mother is concerned as he is still not himself. He appears to be very pale and has not passed urine for 12 hours. He has no other medical problems and is not normally on any medication. On examination you note that he has pale conjunctivae. His blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. You decide to take some blood tests and get the following results:

•    Haemoglobin: 76 g/L; white blood cells: 14200/mm3; platelet count: 50,000/mm3

•    Creatinine: 200 μmol/L (normal: 20–80 μmol/L)

•    Prothrombin time: 13 seconds (control: 12–15 s)

•    Activated partial thromboplastin time: 34 seconds (control: 25–35 s)

What is the most likely diagnosis?
Select one answer only.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

HUS

questions.text: A 10-day-old female neonate presents with vomiting, poor feeding, lethargy, and signs of dehydration. On examination, she is hypotensive and has hyperpigmented genitalia with clitoromegaly. Lab investigations show hyponatremia (Na+ 124 mmol/L), hyperkalemia (K+ 6.8 mmol/L), and hypoglycemia. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

17-hydroxyprogesterone (17-OHP) level

Explanation: The most common form of CAH is 21-hydroxylase deficiency, which leads to elevated 17-OHP. This test is the initial and most specific screening marker.

choices.text: IV hydrocortisone, IV fluids with dextrose and saline

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant with known CAH is brought to the ER with lethargy, vomiting, and hypotension. Labs show Na+ 120 mmol/L, K+ 7.2 mmol/L, and glucose 48 mg/dL. What is the first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

IV hydrocortisone, IV fluids with dextrose and saline

Explanation: This is an adrenal crisis. Immediate resuscitation with IV hydrocortisone and correction of hypovolemia, hyponatremia, and hypoglycemia is lifesaving.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with failure to thrive, recurrent lower respiratory infections, and bulky foul-smelling stools. Chest X-ray shows hyperinflated lungs with bronchial thickening. What is the gold standard diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sweat chloride test

Explanation: Sweat chloride ≥60 mmol/L on pilocarpine iontophoresis confirms the diagnosis. Genetic testing is supportive but not primary in all settings.

choices.text: Autosomal dominant mutation in the FBN1 gene
X-linked recessive mutation in the G6PD gene
Autosomal recessive mutation in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7
Mitochondrial inheritance of CFTR gene mutations

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the genetic basis of cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Autosomal recessive mutation in the CFTR gene on chromosome 7

Explanation: CF is caused by biallelic mutations in the CFTR gene, most commonly the ΔF508 mutation.

choices.text: No modulator therapy is approved for children under 12

questions.text: A 9-year-old child with CF is found to be homozygous for the F508del mutation. What is the most appropriate CFTR modulator therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Elexacaftor-Tezacaftor-Ivacaftor

Explanation: The triple combination is the most effective therapy for patients with F508del homozygous or heterozygous mutations, approved for children 6 years and older in most regions.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with facial puffiness, cola-colored urine, and decreased urine output. His blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg. Urinalysis shows hematuria, RBC casts, and mild proteinuria. Labs reveal low C3, normal C4, and elevated anti-streptolysin O (ASO) titers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Explanation: Classic PSGN features include hematuria, hypertension, low C3 with normal C4, and evidence of a recent streptococcal infection.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with nephrotic syndrome has no response to prednisolone even after 6 weeks. His renal biopsy shows minimal change disease. He has normal renal function. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Initiate tacrolimus therapy

Explanation: In steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome, calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus or cyclosporine) are first-line treatments, especially when biopsy is MCD or FSGS.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child undergoing cardiac surgery is at high risk for AKI. Within 6 hours post-op, her urine output drops, but serum creatinine remains normal. Which of the following biomarkers would most likely indicate early AKI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin (NGAL)

Explanation: NGAL is an early and sensitive biomarker of tubular injury, often elevated before creatinine rises in AKI.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with failure to thrive, polyuria, and dehydration. Labs reveal metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, normal blood pressure, and elevated renin and aldosterone. Urinary calcium is high. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bartter syndrome

Explanation: Bartter syndrome features include metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, polyuria, hypercalciuria, and normal BP due to defective Na-K-2Cl reabsorption in the thick ascending limb.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl with aHUS (atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome) presents with anemia, thrombocytopenia, and AKI. Complement studies show low C3 with normal C4. Genetic testing shows a mutation in complement factor H. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Start eculizumab therapy

Explanation: Eculizumab, a terminal complement inhibitor, is the treatment of choice in aHUS, especially in genetically confirmed complement dysregulation.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets presents with bowing of the legs and poor growth. Lab tests show low serum phosphate, high ALP, normal calcium, and elevated FGF23. He has not responded well to phosphate and calcitriol supplements. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Begin burosumab therapy

Explanation: Burosumab is a monoclonal antibody against FGF23, approved for X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets in children with poor response to conventional therapy.
